elements.content: A new multifunctional semirigid Schiff-base ligand comprising two pyridyl (Py) and two benzimidazolyl (Bim) donor groups, 1,2-bis(1-(1-(pyridine-3-ylmethyl)benzimidazol-2-yl)ethylidene)hydrazine (L), has been synthesized, with which 10 coordination polymers of different transition metal ions, namely, {[AgL]CF3SO3·CH3OH} n (1), {[Ag2 L](p-CH3C6H4SO3)2·2CH3OH} n (2), {[Hg3 LCl6]·CHCl3} n (3), [HgLBr2] n (4), {[CdL(CH3CO2)2H2O]·1.5H2O} n (5), [CdLI2] n (6), {[MnL(H2O)4](ClO4)2·H2O} n (7), [MnL(p-CH3C6H4SO3)2] n (8), {[ZnL 2(CH3CN)2(H2O)2](CF3SO3)2} n (9), and {[ZnL 2(CH3CH2OH)2(H2O)2](p-CH3C6H4SO3)2} n (10) have been prepared and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In complexes 1, 2, and 3, L acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect four metal ions that show the same coordination environment in 1 or different coordination environments in 2 and 3, generating two-dimensional (2D) networks of the (4, 4) net topology. In complexes 4−8, L acts as a bidentate ligand to bridge two metal ions that display diversified coordination environments depending on coordination of the anions and/or water molecules. Complexes 4−7 have similar one-dimensional (1D) chain structures, while 8 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework with dia topology. In complexes 9 and 10, L acts as a monodentate ligand to form mononuclear coordination motifs. Besides versatile coordination modes, ligand L takes on different conformations responsive to donor affinity of different metal ions. In the case that the ligand L is bidentate or monodentate, there are Py and/or Bim groups free of coordination, thus being able to form hydrogen bonds through their noncoordinating NPy or NBim atoms. Therefore, the assembly processes are directed by synergistic effects involving metal−ligand coordination, hydrogen-bonding, π···π stacking, and other influencing factors such as solvents and counteranions.

elements.content: A potential tetratopic ligand containing discriminatory coordination donor sites was synthesized to assemble coordination polymers which exhibit diversified structural topologies corresponding to versatile ligand coordination modes and conformations.
elements.clean_text: A potential tetratopic ligand containing discriminatory coordination donor sites was synthesized to assemble coordination polymers which exhibit diversified structural topologies corresponding to versatile ligand coordination modes and conformations.

elements.content: The design, synthesis, and characterization of coordination polymers represent a fast growing area in coordination chemistry and supramolecular chemistry due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in molecular recognition, ion exchange, adsorption, fluorescence, catalysis, and magnetic properties. Many factors such as the coordination environment of metal centers, the donors set of ligands, solvent molecules, temperature, templates, counteranions, etc. can affect the final architectures. In particular, the structures of the ligands and the coordination fashions of metal ions play key roles in the manipulation of the building blocks, because deliberate modifications on the organic ligand, such as the length, flexibility and symmetry, or coordination restraints on metal ions can dramatically change the ultimate structural topologies of the coordination frameworks. Besides metal−ligand coordination bonding, various kinds of intermolecular weak interactions such as hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking, metal−metal interactions, etc., are also vital in the self-assembly process. In general, self-assembly is based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks in order to generate a well-defined product.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design, synthesis, and characterization of coordination polymers represent a fast growing area in coordination chemistry and supramolecular chemistry due to their intriguing architectures and topologies, as well as their potential applications in molecular recognition, ion exchange, adsorption, fluorescence, catalysis, and magnetic properties. Many factors such as the coordination environment of metal centers, the donors set of ligands, solvent molecules, temperature, templates, counteranions, etc. can affect the final architectures. In particular, the structures of the ligands and the coordination fashions of metal ions play key roles in the manipulation of the building blocks, because deliberate modifications on the organic ligand, such as the length, flexibility and symmetry, or coordination restraints on metal ions can dramatically change the ultimate structural topologies of the coordination frameworks. Besides metal-ligand coordination bonding, various kinds of intermolecular weak interactions such as hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking, metal-metal interactions, etc., are also vital in the self-assembly process. In general, self-assembly is based on complementary and explicit interactions between building blocks in order to generate a well-defined product.

elements.content: We have been working on the supramolecular synthesis of various coordination assemblies with semirigid ligands containing a freely rotatable methylene (-CH2-) juncture between a rigid spacer and heterocyclic arms (benzimidazole derivatives or pyridyl rings), and a great diversity of discrete molecular architectures or infinite coordination polymers have been constructed. In most cases, the ligands are restricted to ditopic linear or tritopic tripodal compounds (Scheme ). In order to extend the ligand to a multifunctional one, we designed and prepared a new tetratopic ligand, 1,2-bis(1-(1-(pyridine-3-ylmethyl)benzimidazol-2-yl)ethylidene)hydrazine (L), which attracted our attention due to the following characteristics: (1) It is a semirigid ligand owing to the -CH2- junctures between the rigid Schiff-base spacer and pyridyl (Py) groups. (2) It includes four potential coordination sites in two different groups: two NBim donors on the benzimidazolyl (Bim) spacer and two NPy donors on the pyridyl arms. (3) The steric hindrance of the methyl groups (-CH3) nearby the NBim atoms makes the coordination ability of NBim and NPy donors quite different, by which we may be able to control the number of N donors involved in coordination by choosing a suitable metal ion. (4) Different from many other tetradentate ligands, the donors atoms are orientated in a side-mode other than the normal end-mode (Scheme ), giving rise to more possible coordination and conformations modes (Scheme ). Herein we report 10 complexes assembled from this new ligand, which coordinates with different metal ions in different ways to act as mono-, bi-, or tetradentate ligands, affording a series of coordination polymers varying from one-dimension (1D) to three-dimensions (3D).

In most cases, the ligands are restricted to ditopic linear or tritopic tripodal compounds (Scheme ). elements.content: The ligand L features multifunctional donor groups: two rigid Bim groups incorporated in a Schiff-base spacer and two rotatable Py groups linked by flexible methylene (-CH2-) junctures; thus it is a tetratopic ligand characteristic of semirigidity. Various coordination modes and ligand conformations could be presented by L depending on how many nitrogen atoms are involved in dative-bonding or hydrogen-bonding and how the two Py groups are orientated. Scheme illustrates three kinds of coordination modes observed in this work. Since all the Py and Bim ends contain a coordination site with the NPy and NBim donors being able to directly bind the metal ions, L can act as a tetradentate ligand and can be regarded as a four-connecting linker in a topological view (as in complexes 1−3). On the other hand, the coordination sites provided by Py groups and Bim groups are not equivalent and expectative of different coordination abilities. Because of the steric hindrance of the methyl group (-CH3) nearby the NBim donors, the dative-bonding of the Bim group is understandably weaker than the Py group as observed in other similar ligands; thus the Bim groups may remain uncoordinated under certain conditions. In such a case, L can serve as a bidentate ligand to join two metal ions, and the noncoordinating NBim atoms may behave as hydrogen bond acceptors to increase the dimensionality of the coordination network (as in complexes 4−8). L can also act as a monodentate ligand when the two Bim groups and one of the two Py groups remain uncoordinated (as in complexes 9 and 10). Again, those noncoordinating NBim and NPy atoms can become potential hydrogen bond acceptors.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Coordination and Conformation Modes of L 

The ligand L features multifunctional donor groups: two rigid Bim groups incorporated in a Schiff-base spacer and two rotatable Py groups linked by flexible methylene (-CH2-) junctures; thus it is a tetratopic ligand characteristic of semirigidity. Various coordination modes and ligand conformations could be presented by L depending on how many nitrogen atoms are involved in dative-bonding or hydrogen-bonding and how the two Py groups are orientated. Scheme  illustrates three kinds of coordination modes observed in this work. Since all the Py and Bim ends contain a coordination site with the NPy and NBim donors being able to directly bind the metal ions, L can act as a tetradentate ligand and can be regarded as a four-connecting linker in a topological view (as in complexes 1-3). On the other hand, the coordination sites provided by Py groups and Bim groups are not equivalent and expectative of different coordination abilities. Because of the steric hindrance of the methyl group (-CH3) nearby the NBim donors, the dative-bonding of the Bim group is understandably weaker than the Py group as observed in other similar ligands; thus the Bim groups may remain uncoordinated under certain conditions. In such a case, L can serve as a bidentate ligand to join two metal ions, and the noncoordinating NBim atoms may behave as hydrogen bond acceptors to increase the dimensionality of the coordination network (as in complexes 4-8). L can also act as a monodentate ligand when the two Bim groups and one of the two Py groups remain uncoordinated (as in complexes 9 and 10). Again, those noncoordinating NBim and NPy atoms can become potential hydrogen bond acceptors.

elements.content: The flexibility of L is contributed by the methylene junctures between the Bim groups and the Py groups. In our previous work we have summarized that there are four possible conformations for a semirigid ditopic ligand containing Py groups in the “end-mode”. In the present tetratopic ligand L, the possible conformations increase to six in the “side-mode” as shown in Scheme . The two 3-Py groups of L can be located on either the same or opposite sides of the spacer, resulting in cis- or trans-conformations. The lone pair electron on NPy donor can be orientated in either nearly parallel or vertical directions with respect to the spacer rod, resulting in differentiable dispositions of the four donors. The “cis-a” and “trans-a” conformations are defined as vertical orientation of the two NPy atoms with respect to the spacer rod, while the “cis-b” and “trans-b” conformations are defined as parallel orientation of the two NPy atoms with respect to the spacer rod. The possible “cis-c” and “trans-c” conformations may also exist with one NPy atom parallelly orientated while the other is vertically orientated. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of the present 10 complexes reveal that, except for “trans-c” conformation, all other conformations of ligand L are present: “cis-a” in complex 1, “cis-b” in complex 9, “cis -c” in complex 10, “trans-a” in complex 2, and “trans-b” in complexes 3−8. We can choose the two torsion angles of NBim−CMethylene−CPy-3−CPy-2 which directly determine the conformational relationship between the Py groups and the rigid bis-benzimidazol Schiff-base spacer to describe the orientations of two Py groups. As listed in Table , these angles are close to either 0 or 180° in different complexes, confirming the assigned conformations discussed above.

The common structural feature in complexes 1−3 is that L acts as a tetradentate ligand and the resulting coordination polymers have the same (4, 4) network topology. However, the building blocks and the linkers between them are different in these three complexes. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a space group Cmca. As shown in Figure a, the overall coordination geometry of the Ag(I) ion can be described as a distorted tetrahedron consisting of two NPy donors and two NBim donors from four different ligands. The two terminal Py groups in L take on the “cis-a” conformation and link up two Ag (I) ions such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, both the metal ions and the L units serve as 4-connecting nodes. If we use the center of N−N bond to represent the L node, connections between the metal nodes and the L nodes alternately will give rise to a 2D (4, 4) topological network as shown in Figure b. Because of the difference between NBim and NPy donors, two different grids are formed. One is a parallelogram with the side lengths of 7.019 Å and 5.194 Å, while the other has the same side length but makes an irregular quadrilateral. In the crystal lattice such 2D networks are stacked in parallel separated by anions and solvent molecules ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures: I. 2D Networks of (4, 4) Topology in Complexes 1-3 

The common structural feature in complexes 1-3 is that L acts as a tetradentate ligand and the resulting coordination polymers have the same (4, 4) network topology. However, the building blocks and the linkers between them are different in these three complexes. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with a space group Cmca. As shown in Figure a, the overall coordination geometry of the Ag(I) ion can be described as a distorted tetrahedron consisting of two NPy donors and two NBim donors from four different ligands. The two terminal Py groups in L take on the "cis-a" conformation and link up two Ag (I) ions such that a 2D grid is formed. In this grid network, both the metal ions and the L units serve as 4-connecting nodes. If we use the center of N-N bond to represent the L node, connections between the metal nodes and the L nodes alternately will give rise to a 2D (4, 4) topological network as shown in Figure b. Because of the difference between NBim and NPy donors, two different grids are formed. One is a parallelogram with the side lengths of 7.019 Å and 5.194 Å, while the other has the same side length but makes an irregular quadrilateral. In the crystal lattice such 2D networks are stacked in parallel separated by anions and solvent molecules ().

elements.content: (a) The coordination environment of Ag(I) ion in 1. (b) 2D network with the (4,4) topology represented by yellow rods as connections. All solvent molecules, CF3SO3 − anions, and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environment of Ag(I) ion in 1. (b) 2D network with the (4,4) topology represented by yellow rods as connections. All solvent molecules, CF3SO3 - anions, and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Complex 2 exhibits an infinite rhombic grid structure extending in the ac plane, showing the same (4, 4) network topology but different connecting fashion. Similar to 1, L is tetradentate and can be simplified as 4-connecting node. However, the Ag(I) ion is in a linear coordination geometry to bridge two ligands, representing a linker between two L nodes (Figure ). Since the grid in 2 consists of four metals and four ligands (M4L4) in comparison to the M2L2 grid in 1, more spacious (4, 4) network is formed with the parallelogrammic grid having dimensions of 11.43 × 10.06 Å2. When viewed along the a direction, we can see that the networks extend as undulating layers intercalated by p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anions and MeOH molecules (). In contrast to 1, the ligand in 2 adopts the “trans-a” conformation, having a crystallographically imposed inversion center in the middle of N−N bond. It is also noticeable that the Ag(I) ions in 2 either connect two NPy donors or bridge two NBim donors, different to 1 that the same Ag(I) ion can be simultaneously coordinated by both NPy and NBim donors. In general, the Ag−NPy distances in 1 and 2 (2.240(3) and 2.128(4) Å, respectively) are shorter than Ag−NBim distances (2.524(4) and 2.165(4) Å, respectively), which are different from those observed in other related structures. This may be due to the steric hindrance of methyl group nearby the NBim donors, confirming a weaker coordination ability of the Bim group than the Py group. Furthermore, the corresponding Ag−N bond distances of 1 are longer than those of 2. This is apparently owing to their coordination geometry difference: in 1 Ag(I) ion is 4-coordinated by four ligands while in 2 Ag(I) ion is 2-coordinated by only two ligands.

elements.content: In complex 3, L takes on “trans-b” conformation with all Py groups and Bim groups are involved in coordination with Hg(II) ions. Similar to 2, the NBim donors and the NPy donors coordinate separately with the Hg(II) ions without crossing bonding. Moreover, the Hg(II) motifs connecting Py groups and Bim groups are different as depicted in Figure . When connecting Py groups, each Hg(II) ion shows distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry composed of two NPy atoms from two ligands and two terminal Cl− anions. When connecting Bim groups, two Hg(II) ions are bridged by two μ-Cl− anions, and further coordinated by two NBim donors from two different ligands and two terminal Cl− anions, thus forming a Hg2Cl2(μ-Cl)2N2 motif which is a common structural unit in complexes of Hg(II) halides. This difference may be because if two Bim groups bind to the same Hg(II) ion as Py groups do, the Hg(II) coordination environment will become congested. As a consequence the HgCl3NBim coordination geometry leads to a shorter Hg−NBim bond distance (2.161(5) Å) than the Hg−NPy bond distance (2.376(5) Å) in an HgCl2(NPy)2 geometry. From a topology view, L can be regarded as 4-connecting node while Hg(II) motifs can be considered as connector, thus resulting in (4, 4) topological network as demonstrated in Figure b. The simplified parallelogrammic grid is of 12.74 × 10.68 Å2 dimensions. The crystal packing analysis reveals weaving layers stacked in a parallel fashion, and in between the layers the solvated CHCl3 molecules are encapsulated ().
elements.clean_text: In complex 3, L takes on "trans-b" conformation with all Py groups and Bim groups are involved in coordination with Hg(II) ions. Similar to 2, the NBim donors and the NPy donors coordinate separately with the Hg(II) ions without crossing bonding. Moreover, the Hg(II) motifs connecting Py groups and Bim groups are different as depicted in Figure . When connecting Py groups, each Hg(II) ion shows distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry composed of two NPy atoms from two ligands and two terminal Cl- anions. When connecting Bim groups, two Hg(II) ions are bridged by two μ-Cl- anions, and further coordinated by two NBim donors from two different ligands and two terminal Cl- anions, thus forming a Hg2Cl2(μ-Cl)2N2 motif which is a common structural unit in complexes of Hg(II) halides. This difference may be because if two Bim groups bind to the same Hg(II) ion as Py groups do, the Hg(II) coordination environment will become congested. As a consequence the HgCl3NBim coordination geometry leads to a shorter Hg-NBim bond distance (2.161(5) Å) than the Hg-NPy bond distance (2.376(5) Å) in an HgCl2(NPy)2 geometry. From a topology view, L can be regarded as 4-connecting node while Hg(II) motifs can be considered as connector, thus resulting in (4, 4) topological network as demonstrated in Figure b. The simplified parallelogrammic grid is of 12.74 × 10.68 Å2 dimensions. The crystal packing analysis reveals weaving layers stacked in a parallel fashion, and in between the layers the solvated CHCl3 molecules are encapsulated ().

elements.content: The common structural feature in complexes 4−7 is that L behaves as a ditopic ligand displaying the “trans-b” conformation, and only the Py groups participate in coordination while the noncoordinating Bim groups provide NBim atoms as hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Complexes 4 and 6 are isostructures; therefore, only 4 will be discussed as a representative. The building blocks in complex 4 are [HgLBr2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain as seen in Figure a. The two Py groups of the ligand are linked to two different Hg(II) ions which in turn connect two different ligands. The coordination geometry of the Hg(II) ion is a distorted tetrahedron, composed of two NPy atoms from two different ligands and two terminal Br− anions. The NPy−Hg−NPy and Br−Hg−Br angles are 86.15(19) and 144.98(3)°, respectively. The individual 1D chains in complexes 4 and 6 are arranged in parallel with each other and further linked by weak nonclassical C−H···NBim (C···NBim 3.337 Å) and C−H···Br (C···Br 3.876 Å) hydrogen bonds as shown in Figure b. Every [HgLBr2] unit contains four hydrogen-bond acceptors and four hydrogen-bond donors, in which one acceptor and one donor form two hydrogen bonds to link one adjacent chain. In such a way, every 1D chain is connected to four adjacent 1D chains, generating the overall 3D framework as seen in Figure c and .

1D Chain Structures and Supramolecular Interactions in Complexes 4-7 

The common structural feature in complexes 4-7 is that L behaves as a ditopic ligand displaying the "trans-b" conformation, and only the Py groups participate in coordination while the noncoordinating Bim groups provide NBim atoms as hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Complexes 4 and 6 are isostructures; therefore, only 4 will be discussed as a representative. The building blocks in complex 4 are [HgLBr2] units which are connected in a zigzag way to form a 1D polymeric chain as seen in Figure a. The two Py groups of the ligand are linked to two different Hg(II) ions which in turn connect two different ligands. The coordination geometry of the Hg(II) ion is a distorted tetrahedron, composed of two NPy atoms from two different ligands and two terminal Br- anions. The NPy-Hg-NPy and Br-Hg-Br angles are 86.15(19) and 144.98(3)°, respectively. The individual 1D chains in complexes 4 and 6 are arranged in parallel with each other and further linked by weak nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅NBim (C⋅⋅⋅NBim 3.337 Å) and C-H⋅⋅⋅Br (C⋅⋅⋅Br 3.876 Å) hydrogen bonds as shown in Figure b. Every [HgLBr2] unit contains four hydrogen-bond acceptors and four hydrogen-bond donors, in which one acceptor and one donor form two hydrogen bonds to link one adjacent chain. In such a way, every 1D chain is connected to four adjacent 1D chains, generating the overall 3D framework as seen in Figure c and .

elements.content: When Cd(CH3CO2)2 was used to react with L, we got a 1D coordination polymer 5. The Cd(II) ion is seven-coordinated by two NPy donors (Cd−NPy 2.359(5) Å) from two distinct ligands, four O atoms from two CH3COO− anions, and one O atom from water molecule (Figure a); therefore, Cd(II) ion actually serves as 2-connecting node to join L into a zigzag polymeric chain. The asymmetric unit contains half of a ligand which is located on an inversion center, half of a Cd(II) ion which is located on a 2-fold axis, and 0.75 disordered water molecules. Again, it is the noncoordinating NBim atoms that act as hydrogen bond acceptors to form C−H···NBim (C···NBim 3.359 Å) hydrogen bonds, linking the 1D chains into a 2D layer extending in the ac plane (Figure b). In addition, O−H···O (O···O 2.687 Å) hydrogen bonds are formed between CH3COO− anions and water molecules as illustrated in Figure c, which result in hydrogen-bonding chains running in the c direction. Therefore, the overall crystal packing is sustained by above C−H···N and O−H···O hydrogen bonds to direct arrangement of the 1D coordination polymers in the crystal lattice, leading to a supramolecular 3D framework as shown in Figure d. Potential channels are provided by such 3D framework to guest solvated water molecules. If only the coordination polymers and anions are retained, the framework has a 442 Å3 potential solvent accessible area (12%) estimated by PLATON.

elements.content: Complex 7 also displays a 1D polymeric structure. L acts as a ditopic ligand and coordinates with two Mn(II) ions via Py groups. As shown in Figure a, each Mn(II) center in 7 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination sphere which is defined by two NPy atoms from two ligands in the axial positions, together with four O donors from four water molecules in the equatorial plane. The asymmetric unit contains half of a ligand, half of a Mn(II) ion, one ClO4 − anion, two coordinating water molecules, and half of a noncoordinating water molecule. All O atoms from ClO4 − anion and water molecules and the noncoordinating NBim atoms are involved in formation of hydrogen bonds (see Table ). As depicted in Figure c, a hydrogen-bonding ribbon is made up of O−H···O and O−H···N hydrogen bonds, extending along the a direction and joining the 1D coordination polymers into 2D layer in the ac plane. In addition, π···π stacking interactions are formed between Bim rings from neighboring 1D polymers (Figure b), which further stabilize the 2D hydrogen-bonding layer. In the crystal lattice such layers are parallelly packed in the 011̅ direction ().

Crystallographic analysis reveals that complex 8 is a 3D structure due to coordination of all p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anions. The coordination geometry of Mn(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with two NPy donors from two different ligands and four O donors from four different p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anions (Figure a). L takes on a “trans-b” conformation, only providing NPy atoms as coordination donors to connect two Mn(II) ions. In contrast to the 1D structures in 4−7 where two “trans-b” conformational ligands are oppositely arranged around the metal center, the NPy−Mn−NPy angle in 8 is 85.34(16)°. This is because every two Mn(II) ions are bridged by two p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anions to generate a 1D manganese chain along the a direction (Figure b), leaving two adjacent coordination sites for L to bind to Mn(II) ion. Each manganese chain is connected to four other neighboring chains by four bidentate L, thus consolidating a 3D framework as shown in Figure c. If we define the Mn(II) ions as nodes, and bridging L and anions as connections, 8 can be simplified as a diamondoid net (dia) as represented in Figure d. The shortest Mn(II)···Mn(II) distance along the manganese chain is 5.363 Å, and the shortest Mn(II)···Mn(II) distance between two adjacent manganese chains is 15.560 Å. Formation of 3D structure prevents the noncoordinating NBim atoms from forming hydrogen bonds.

3D Framework of the Diamondoid Topology in Complex 8

The coordination geometry of Mn(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with two NPy donors from two different ligands and four O donors from four different p-CH3C6H4SO3 - anions (Figure a). L takes on a "trans-b" conformation, only providing NPy atoms as coordination donors to connect two Mn(II) ions. In contrast to the 1D structures in 4-7 where two "trans-b" conformational ligands are oppositely arranged around the metal center, the NPy-Mn-NPy angle in 8 is 85.34(16)°. This is because every two Mn(II) ions are bridged by two p-CH3C6H4SO3 - anions to generate a 1D manganese chain along the a direction (Figure b), leaving two adjacent coordination sites for L to bind to Mn(II) ion. Each manganese chain is connected to four other neighboring chains by four bidentate L, thus consolidating a 3D framework as shown in Figure c. If we define the Mn(II) ions as nodes, and bridging L and anions as connections, 8 can be simplified as a diamondoid net (dia) as represented in Figure d. The shortest Mn(II)⋅⋅⋅Mn(II) distance along the manganese chain is 5.363 Å, and the shortest Mn(II)⋅⋅⋅Mn(II) distance between two adjacent manganese chains is 15.560 Å. elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 9 contains half of a Zn(II) ion, one ligand, one coordinating water molecule, one coordinating CH3CN molecule, and one noncoordinating CF3SO3 − anion. The local coordination environment around the Zn(II) center can be described as an octahedron as shown in Figure a. It is clear that the coordination motif is a discrete mononuclear complex. The central Zn(II) ion is coordinated by the Py group other than the Bim group due to the steric congestion around the NBim donors, similar to the 1D and 3D complexes 4−8. It is a surprise that, although we add excess metal ions, one of the NPy atoms still remains uncoordinated, and L takes on a “cis-b” conformation in 9 and serves as a monodentate ligand. Instead, the noncoordinating NPy atom and NBim atoms become effective hydrogen-bonding acceptors which assemble the mononuclear basic units into a 3D framework through formation of C−H···N hydrogen bonds listed in Table . As shown in Figure b, every two mononuclear units are linked by two C−H···NPy hydrogen bonds formed between noncoordinating NPy atoms and the methyl group of the coordinated CH3CN molecule, thus generating a double-stranded 1D chain which can be considered to comprise a series of M2L2 rings. The Zn(II)···Zn(II) separation in each ring is 14.72 Å. Such chains are stacked via π···π interactions (3.39 Å) to sustain a 2D layer as seen in Figure c. Furthermore, the C−H···NBim hydrogen bonds are formed between the noncoordinating NBim atoms and the hydrogen atoms on Py groups, which link the M2L2 rings belonging two neighboring 1D double-stranded chains as depicted in Figure d. Besides the C−H···N, there are O−H···O hydrogen bonds formed between O atoms of coordinated water molecules and O atoms of CF3SO3 − anions (). Overall, these C−H···N and O−H···O hydrogen bonds together with the π···π interactions consolidate the mononuclear coordination motifs into a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text:
Mononuclear Motifs and Dimensional Increase via Hydrogen-Bonding in Complexes 9 and 10 

The asymmetric unit of complex 9 contains half of a Zn(II) ion, one ligand, one coordinating water molecule, one coordinating CH3CN molecule, and one noncoordinating CF3SO3 - anion. The local coordination environment around the Zn(II) center can be described as an octahedron as shown in Figure a. It is clear that the coordination motif is a discrete mononuclear complex. The central Zn(II) ion is coordinated by the Py group other than the Bim group due to the steric congestion around the NBim donors, similar to the 1D and 3D complexes 4-8. It is a surprise that, although we add excess metal ions, one of the NPy atoms still remains uncoordinated, and L takes on a "cis-b" conformation in 9 and serves as a monodentate ligand. Instead, the noncoordinating NPy atom and NBim atoms become effective hydrogen-bonding acceptors which assemble the mononuclear basic units into a 3D framework through formation of C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds listed in Table . As shown in Figure b, every two mononuclear units are linked by two C-H⋅⋅⋅NPy hydrogen bonds formed between noncoordinating NPy atoms and the methyl group of the coordinated CH3CN molecule, thus generating a double-stranded 1D chain which can be considered to comprise a series of M2L2 rings. The Zn(II)⋅⋅⋅Zn(II) separation in each ring is 14.72 Å. Such chains are stacked via π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (3.39 Å) to sustain a 2D layer as seen in Figure c. Furthermore, the C-H⋅⋅⋅NBim hydrogen bonds are formed between the noncoordinating NBim atoms and the hydrogen atoms on Py groups, which link the M2L2 rings belonging two neighboring 1D double-stranded chains as depicted in Figure d. Besides the C-H⋅⋅⋅N, there are O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds formed between O atoms of coordinated water molecules and O atoms of CF3SO3 - anions (). Overall, these C-H⋅⋅⋅N and O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds together with the π⋅⋅⋅π interactions consolidate the mononuclear coordination motifs into a 3D framework.

Complex 10 also shows a mononuclear coordination unit, as shown in Figure a, which contains one ligand, one coordinating EtOH molecule, one coordinating water molecule, and one noncoordinating p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anion. In contrast to complex 9, the ligand takes on a “cis-c” conformation in complex 10, thereby leading to completely different hydrogen-bonding fashions compared to those of 9. The mononuclear basic units are assembled into a 1D chain by O−H···O hydrogen bonds formed between the O atoms of the coordinated water molecules and O atoms of the p-CH3C6H4SO3 − anions as shown in Figure b. Furthermore, such chains are joined by C−H···NPy hydrogen bonds formed between the noncoordinating NPy atoms and the hydrogen atoms on Bim groups (Figure c), thus generating a 3D framework. If we denote the basic mononuclear unit as a node, the whole framework can be described as a 412.63-pcu net as represented in Figure d.

elements.content: From above crystal structures description from complexes 1−10, we can see that the choice of the metal ions apparently affects assembly of the final products not only due to their different coordination geometries, but also due to their inducement to the various coordination and conformation modes of L. Schemes and demonstrate a general relationship between the complexes structural topologies and ligand coordination modes, which is correlated to the metal affinity toward O or N donors (or hardness of metal ions according to empirical soft−hard acid theory). It seems that the soft metal ions, such as Ag(I) and Hg(II), prefer binding all four potential coordination sites of L, and therefore, L acts as a tetradentate ligand in Ag(I) and Hg(II) complexes. When harder metal ions, from Cd(II) to Mn(II) and Zn(II), are used, only NPy donors are involved in coordination, leaving NBim atoms as potential sites for supramolecular interactions. In the cases of Cd(II) and Mn(II) complexes, L acts as a ditopic ligand, but it is a little unusual in the case of Zn(II) complexes in which L only acts as a monodentate ligand. This implies that other influencing factors, such as solvents and anions, have to be taken into consideration in assembly of coordination polymers with the multifunctional ligand L. The reason why the multiply dentate L displays distinctive coordination behaviors toward different mental ions lies in the fact that the NPy and NBim donors in L have a distinguishable coordination ability, which can be subtly sensed by different metal ions. Therefore, L could be a candidate to generate diversified coordination polymers subject to selection of metal centers as well as proper control of other common influencing factors.
elements.clean_text:
Metal-Direction in Assembly of Coordination Polymers

From above crystal structures description from complexes 1-10, we can see that the choice of the metal ions apparently affects assembly of the final products not only due to their different coordination geometries, but also due to their inducement to the various coordination and conformation modes of L. Schemes  and  demonstrate a general relationship between the complexes structural topologies and ligand coordination modes, which is correlated to the metal affinity toward O or N donors (or hardness of metal ions according to empirical soft-hard acid theory). It seems that the soft metal ions, such as Ag(I) and Hg(II), prefer binding all four potential coordination sites of L, and therefore, L acts as a tetradentate ligand in Ag(I) and Hg(II) complexes. When harder metal ions, from Cd(II) to Mn(II) and Zn(II), are used, only NPy donors are involved in coordination, leaving NBim atoms as potential sites for supramolecular interactions. In the cases of Cd(II) and Mn(II) complexes, L acts as a ditopic ligand, but it is a little unusual in the case of Zn(II) complexes in which L only acts as a monodentate ligand. This implies that other influencing factors, such as solvents and anions, have to be taken into consideration in assembly of coordination polymers with the multifunctional ligand L. The reason why the multiply dentate L displays distinctive coordination behaviors toward different mental ions lies in the fact that the NPy and NBim donors in L have a distinguishable coordination ability, which can be subtly sensed by different metal ions. Therefore, L could be a candidate to generate diversified coordination polymers subject to selection of metal centers as well as proper control of other common influencing factors.

elements.content: The thermostability of the coordination polymers has been checked by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure shows the TG diagram of the complex 7, {[MnL(H2O)4]·(ClO4)2·H2O} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25 to 135 °C, amounting to about 10% and corresponding to escape of all water molecules (calculated 11%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 260 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 630 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 200−300 °C (), which is typical for metal−organic frameworks containing large organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses

The thermostability of the coordination polymers has been checked by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure  shows the TG diagram of the complex 7, {[MnL(H2O)4]⋅(ClO4)2⋅H2O} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25 to 135 °C, amounting to about 10% and corresponding to escape of all water molecules (calculated 11%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 260 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 630 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 200-300 °C (), which is typical for metal-organic frameworks containing large organic ligands.

elements.content: A multifunctional Schiff-base ligand L containing both Py and Bim coordination groups has been designed and synthesized. Its preliminary coordination chemistry on Ag(I), Hg(II), Cd(II), Mn(II), and Zn(II) ions has been studied, resulting in 10 complexes showing diversified structural topologies from 1D chain to 3D dia framework. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of these coordination polymers reveal versatile coordination modes of L, including monodentate, bidentate, and tetradentate, and a series of ligand conformations, which are responsible for different structural topologies. It is found that functionalization of the rigid bis-benzimidazole Schiff-base ligand by attaching two 3-pyridylmethyl groups could lead to introduction of flexibility and discriminatory donors which are responsive to different metal ions. The NPy donors display stronger coordination ability than the NBim donors, while both of them could be potential hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Therefore, the assembly of coordination polymers with this ligand is expected to be first directed by the coordination modes of L toward different metal ions, and then extended into higher dimensional structures via hydrogen-bonding whenever it is possible. In addition, the π···π stacking interactions play important roles in sustaining the overall framework where it is needed. In a word, the synergistic effect of the metal−ligand coordination, hydrogen-bonding and π···π stacking has been observed in construction of diversified supramolecular frameworks subject to coordination nature of the ligand L, metal ions, and counteranions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A multifunctional Schiff-base ligand L containing both Py and Bim coordination groups has been designed and synthesized. Its preliminary coordination chemistry on Ag(I), Hg(II), Cd(II), Mn(II), and Zn(II) ions has been studied, resulting in 10 complexes showing diversified structural topologies from 1D chain to 3D dia framework. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of these coordination polymers reveal versatile coordination modes of L, including monodentate, bidentate, and tetradentate, and a series of ligand conformations, which are responsible for different structural topologies. It is found that functionalization of the rigid bis-benzimidazole Schiff-base ligand by attaching two 3-pyridylmethyl groups could lead to introduction of flexibility and discriminatory donors which are responsive to different metal ions. The NPy donors display stronger coordination ability than the NBim donors, while both of them could be potential hydrogen-bonding acceptors. Therefore, the assembly of coordination polymers with this ligand is expected to be first directed by the coordination modes of L toward different metal ions, and then extended into higher dimensional structures via hydrogen-bonding whenever it is possible. In addition, the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions play important roles in sustaining the overall framework where it is needed. In a word, the synergistic effect of the metal-ligand coordination, hydrogen-bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking has been observed in construction of diversified supramolecular frameworks subject to coordination nature of the ligand L, metal ions, and counteranions.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H, N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm−1 region. The X-ray powder diffraction was recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40 kV, 40 mA with a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument under air by heating the sample from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procredures

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were of reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H, N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. The X-ray powder diffraction was recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40 kV, 40 mA with a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out on a NETZSCH TG 209 instrument under air by heating the sample from 25 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

elements.content: The ligand L was prepared in three steps as depicted in Scheme . In the first step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole was synthesized according to the literature. In the second step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole (1.60 g, 10.0 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (30 mL), to this solution K2CO3 (4.14 g, 30.0 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred and refluxed. After 0.5 h, 3-(chloromethyl)pyridine hydrochloride (1.63 g, 10 mmol) was added and the mixture was further refluxed for 24 h. After removal of the solvent under vacuum, the residue was washed with water several times. The white solid is 1-(3-pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetylbenzimidazole. yield 65%1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ (ppm): 8.54 (s, 1H), 8.50 (d, 1H, J = 4.3 Hz), 7.92 (d, 1H, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.42 (m, 3H), 7.38 (dd, 1H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 7.19 (dd, 1H J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 5.86 (s, 2H), 2.85 (s, 3H). In the third step, a mixture of N2H4·2HCl (0.53 g, 5.0 mmol) and KOH (0.50 g, 8.93 mmol) was suspended in EtOH (30 mL) and stirred for 0.5 h. 1-(3-Pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetyl benzimidazole (2.50 g, 10.0 mmol) was added and the mixture was heated and stirred for 12 h. The yellow precipitate was separated and washed with water to give the product. Yield 50%. Syntheses and Characterization

1,2-Bis(1-(1-(pyridine-3-ylmethyl)benzimidazol-2-yl)ethylidene)hydrazine (L)

The ligand L was prepared in three steps as depicted in Scheme . In the first step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole was synthesized according to the literature. In the second step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole (1.60 g, 10.0 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (30 mL), to this solution K2CO3 (4.14 g, 30.0 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred and refluxed. After 0.5 h, 3-(chloromethyl)pyridine hydrochloride (1.63 g, 10 mmol) was added and the mixture was further refluxed for 24 h. After removal of the solvent under vacuum, the residue was washed with water several times. The white solid is 1-(3-pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetylbenzimidazole. yield 65%1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ (ppm): 8.54 (s, 1H), 8.50 (d, 1H, J = 4.3 Hz), 7.92 (d, 1H, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.42 (m, 3H), 7.38 (dd, 1H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 7.19 (dd, 1H J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 5.86 (s, 2H), 2.85 (s, 3H). In the third step, a mixture of N2H4⋅2HCl (0.53 g, 5.0 mmol) and KOH (0.50 g, 8.93 mmol) was suspended in EtOH (30 mL) and stirred for 0.5 h. 1-(3-Pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetyl benzimidazole (2.50 g, 10.0 mmol) was added and the mixture was heated and stirred for 12 h. The yellow precipitate was separated and washed with water to give the product. Yield 50%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3038w, 2989w, 2935w, 1608s, 1482m, 1163m, 931w, 827m, 798w, 748s, 711m, 628w. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ (ppm): 8.49 (s, 2H), 8.47 (d, 2H, J = 4.3 Hz), 7.87 (d, 2H, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.33 (m, 6H), 7.25 (dd, 2H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 7.20 (dd, 2H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 5.98 (s, 4H), 2.24 (s, 6H).

elements.content: A solution of AgCF3SO3 (0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (5 mL) was carefully layered onto a solution of L (0.1 mmol) in mixed CHCl3 (5 mL) in a test tube. The solution was left to stand for 5 days at room temperature in the dark, and yellow block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained. Yield: 45%. Anal. Calcd. for C31H31N8O5.5F3SAg: C, 46.51; H, 3.90; N, 14.00. Found: C, 46.14; H, 3.51; N, 13.83%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3449s, 3044w, 2925w, 2853w, 1608m, 1483m, 1279s, 1163s, 1121m, 1029s, 931w, 830m, 798w, 746s, 707m, 638s. Phase purity was verified by powder XRD ().

elements.content:
Perchlorate metal salt and its complex in the presence of organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be used and handled with care.

X-ray Crystallography

Experimental details of the X-ray structural analyses as well as the crystallographic data are provided in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The diffraction data were collected on a Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer equipped with Cu−Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) for complexes 5 and 8, or on the same diffractometer equipped with Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for complexes 1−4, 6, 7, 9 and 10 at 150 K by using φ and ω scans. Analytical adsorption corrections were applied for complex 3. Multiscan adsorption corrections were applied for all others. The structures were solved by the direct methods (SHELXS) and refined by the full matrix least-squares method against F o 2 using the SHELXTL software. The coordinates of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Most of hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the water and EtOH molecules in complexes 7, 9, and 10 were located from electronic map and refined isotropically. In complex 1, F atoms of CF3SO− anion and MeOH solvated molecules are disordered. Fractional occupancy was assigned and refined without adding H atoms. MeOH molecule in complex 2 is also disordered over two positions. Partial refinement was applied and H atoms were not included. One of Cl atom in complex 3 displays slight disorder. The CHCl3 solvated molecule distributes over two sites, and half-occupancy was assigned for each site. The solvated water molecules in complex 5 are disordered over several positions. H atoms of both coordinating and noncoordinating water molecules are not included in refinement. CCDC reference numbers CCDC 706710−706719. For crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format see DOI no. 10.1021/cg801228x.

The ligand L was prepared in three steps as depicted in Scheme . In the first step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole was synthesized according to the literature. In the second step, 2-acetylbenzimidazole (1.60 g, 10.0 mmol) was dissolved in MeCN (30 mL), to this solution K2CO3 (4.14 g, 30.0 mmol) was added, and the mixture was stirred and refluxed. After 0.5 h, 3-(chloromethyl)pyridine hydrochloride (1.63 g, 10 mmol) was added and the mixture was further refluxed for 24 h. After removal of the solvent under vacuum, the residue was washed with water several times. The white solid is 1-(3-pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetylbenzimidazole. yield 65%1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ (ppm): 8.54 (s, 1H), 8.50 (d, 1H, J = 4.3 Hz), 7.92 (d, 1H, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.42 (m, 3H), 7.38 (dd, 1H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 7.19 (dd, 1H J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 5.86 (s, 2H), 2.85 (s, 3H). In the third step, a mixture of N2H4·2HCl (0.53 g, 5.0 mmol) and KOH (0.50 g, 8.93 mmol) was suspended in EtOH (30 mL) and stirred for 0.5 h. 1-(3-Pyridinylmethyl)-2-acetyl benzimidazole (2.50 g, 10.0 mmol) was added and the mixture was heated and stirred for 12 h. The yellow precipitate was separated and washed with water to give the product. Yield 50%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3038w, 2989w, 2935w, 1608s, 1482m, 1163m, 931w, 827m, 798w, 748s, 711m, 628w. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, 25 °C): δ (ppm): 8.49 (s, 2H), 8.47 (d, 2H, J = 4.3 Hz), 7.87 (d, 2H, J = 7.5 Hz), 7.33 (m, 6H), 7.25 (dd, 2H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 7.20 (dd, 2H, J = 3.6 and 9 Hz), 5.98 (s, 4H), 2.24 (s, 6H).

{[AgL]·CF<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>·CH<sub>3</sub>OH}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of AgCF3SO3 (0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (5 mL) was carefully layered onto a solution of L (0.1 mmol) in mixed CHCl3 (5 mL) in a test tube. The solution was left to stand for 5 days at room temperature in the dark, and yellow block crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained. Yield: 45%. Anal. Calcd. for C31H31N8O5.5F3SAg: C, 46.51; H, 3.90; N, 14.00. Found: C, 46.14; H, 3.51; N, 13.83%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3449s, 3044w, 2925w, 2853w, 1608m, 1483m, 1279s, 1163s, 1121m, 1029s, 931w, 830m, 798w, 746s, 707m, 638s. Phase purity was verified by powder XRD ().

{[Ag<sub>2</sub>L]·(<italic toggle="yes">p</italic>-CH<sub>3</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·2CH<sub>3</sub>OH}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was obtained by a similar procedure as for 1 except for using Ag(p-CH3C6H4SO3) instead of AgCF3SO3. Yield: 40%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3442s, 3059w, 1608m, 1485w, 1445m, 1407m, 1203s, 1123m, 1034m, 1009m, 822m, 798m, 751m, 680m. Phase purity was verified by powder XRD ().

[HgLBr<sub>2</sub>]<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>4</bold>)

A solution of HgBr2 (0.1 mmol) and L (0.1 mmol) in mixed CHCl3-THF (5 mL, v/v, 1:1) was stirred for 10 min and filtered out. The clear filtrate was left in a test tube, and slow evaporation of the Et2O resulted in precipitation of yellow crystals. Yield: 22%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3052m, 2924m, 1606s, 1481m, 1171s, 831m, 747s, 703m, 638m. Phase purity was verified by powder XRD ().

The thermostability of the coordination polymers has been checked by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure shows the TG diagram of the complex 7, {[MnL(H2O)4]·(ClO4)2·H2O} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25 to 135 °C, amounting to about 10% and corresponding to escape of all water molecules (calculated 11%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 260 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 630 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 200−300 °C (), which is typical for metal−organic frameworks containing large organic ligands.

{[ZnL<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>CN)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(CF<sub>3</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>9</bold>)

Complex 9 was obtained by a similar procedure as for 5 except for using Zn(CF3SO3)2 ·6H2O instead of Cd(CH3CO2)2·2H2O and CH3CN instead of MeOH. Yield: 30%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3460s, 3044w, 2930w, 2225m, 1609m, 1483m, 1278s, 1165s, 1123m, 1027s, 932w, 830w, 795w, 746w, 704m. Phase purity was verified by powder XRD ().

Thermogravimetric Analyses

The thermostability of the coordination polymers has been checked by recording thermogravimetric (TG) curves of selected complexes. As a representative, Figure  shows the TG diagram of the complex 7, {[MnL(H2O)4]⋅(ClO4)2⋅H2O} n . Three main steps of weight losses were observed in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first step occurs in the range of 25 to 135 °C, amounting to about 10% and corresponding to escape of all water molecules (calculated 11%). The complex remains undecomposed up to 260 °C where the second weight loss starts. Complete decomposition of the complex finishes at about 630 °C. The general decomposition temperature of other complexes is in the range of 200-300 °C (), which is typical for metal-organic frameworks containing large organic ligands.

{[ZnL2(CH3CN)2(H2O)2]⋅(CF3SO3)2} n  (9)

Complex 9 was obtained by a similar procedure as for 5 except for using Zn(CF3SO3)2 ⋅6H2O instead of Cd(CH3CO2)2⋅2H2O and CH3CN instead of MeOH. Yield: 30%.
